abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Amazon Basin Malaria
            Control Project for Brazil were as follows: outcomes were
            highly satisfactory, project sustainability was likely, Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            also satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: early
            diagnosis and immediate treatment of malaria to reduce
            mortality is a cost-effective intervention for reducing the
            burden of malaria. It should be the centerpiece of any
            malaria control strategy. Focused application of
            insecticides for vector control based on the epidemiological
            stratification by municipalities and by community, according
            to levels of risk of malaria transmission, offers an
            efficient and environment friendly alternative to
            traditional widespread insecticide application for vector
            eradication. Management contracts, performance indicators,
            monitoring, supervision, and evaluation are crucial to
            successful project implementation. Active Bank supervision
            at state and municipal level, as well as at the federal
            level, reinforced the need for decentralized management and
            accountability. Competent and stable project management is
            necessary for continuity of the project in a changing
            political environment. In the early 1990s political
            appointees in a volatile political environment almost
            brought the project to a halt. Government commitment is key
            for the project. States with more committed governors were
            more successful than others. At the federal level, strong
            support by the minister between 1993 and 1995 accelerated
            project implementation.
